Description: THROUGH THIS PROPOSAL NOAA WILL FUND OPERATIONAL EXPENSES INCLUDING 7 STAFF POSITIONS, PUBLIC OUTREACH ASSOCIATED WITH THE DEVELOPMENT OF AN ACTION STRATEGY FOR THE SE FL CORAL REEF ECOSYSTEM CONSERVATION AREA, AND A LONG-TERM CORAL REEF MONITORING PROGRAM. THE LONG-TERM CORAL REEF MONITORING PROGRAM IS CONDUCTED OVER 22 PERMANENT SAMPLING SITES WITHIN THE 105-MILE SOUTHEAST FLORIDA REGION. THE 22 PERMANENT SITES (EIGHT IN MIAMI-DADE COUNTY, SEVEN IN BROWARD COUNTY, FIVE IN PALM BEACH COUNTY, AND TWO IN MARTIN COUNTY) ARE COMPRISED OF SEVEN SITES IN THE NEARSHORE RIDGE COMPLEX, THREE SITES IN THE INNER REEF, FOUR SITES IN THE MIDDLE REEF, AND EIGHT SITES IN THE OUTER REEF. TEMPERATURE LOGGERS ARE DEPLOYED AT ALL 22 SITES WHERE THEY ARE SECURED TO EXITING REBAR STAKES 10 CM ABOVE THE SUBSTRATE. WITHIN EACH OF THE 22 SITES, DIVERS WILL CONDUCT MONITORING ACTIVITIES AT FOUR DIFFERENT NON-CONTIGUOUS STATIONS. A GROUP OF 4 DIVERS WILL ACCESS THE SITES FROM A VESSEL. DETAILED UNDERWATER SITE

THE UNIVERSITY OF ALABAMA WORKING WITH MOTE MARINE LABORATORY AND UNIVERSITY OF DELAWARE WILL CHARACTERIZE ALGAL FLUORESCENCE THAT CORRELATES TO THE BLEACHING RESPONSE IN NURSERY-REARED ELKHORN CORAL (ACROPORA PALMATA) AND STAGHORN CORAL (ACROPORA CERVICORNIS), TWO CORALS THAT ARE HEAVILY USED IN REEF RESTORATION PROJECTS THROUGHOUT THE FLORIDA KEYS AND THE CARIBBEAN. THE UNIVERSITY OF ALABAMA AND PARTNERS WILL USE THE FLUORESCENCE DATA TO DETERMINE PROXIES THAT PROVIDE THE HIGHEST CORRELATION TO BLEACHING. THE UNIVERSITY OF ALABAMA WILL USE THESE PROXIES TO PREDICT THERMAL TOLERANCE IN DIFFERENT CORAL COLONIES WITHOUT NEEDING TO CONDUCT INVASIVE HEAT EXPOSURE EXPERIMENTS. THE ULTIMATE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CREATE A BROADLY ACCESSIBLE TOOL THAT ACCURATELY PREDICTS THERMAL TOLERANCE OF NURSERY-REARED CORALS AND PROVIDE A RELIABLE SET OF NON-DESTRUCTIVE INDICATORS THAT IDENTIFY RESILIENT CORAL GENOTYPES FOR PRIORITIZED TRANSPLANTING, RESTORATION, AND CONSERVATION EFFORTS.

WILDAID WILL SUPPORT THE FOLLOWING ACTIVITIES IN THE PALAU PROTECTED AREAS NETWORK (PAN): 1) A FIELD TRAINING PROGRAM ON VESSELS TO ENSURE COMPREHENSIVE RANGER TRAINING AND TO CREATE LEADERSHIP OPPORTUNITIES WITHIN THE PAN, 2) A CONTINUOUS PROFESSIONAL TRAINING (CPT) THAT ADVANCES RANGER KNOWLEDGE AND ENSURES ITS RETENTION THROUGH THE YEARS, AND 3) ESTABLISHMENT OF A LEGAL SUPPORT POSITION/LAWYER FOR THE PAN OFFICE TO BETTER PROSECUTE ENVIRONMENTAL AND FISHERIES INFRACTIONS AND IMPROVE LEGISLATIVE LANGUAGE FOR RESOURCE PROTECTION AUTHORITIES. WILDAID MARINE'S PROJECT WILL CONTINUE TO BUILD INTERNATIONAL CAPACITY FOR THE REGION AND PROVIDE A REPLICABLE AND SCALABLE MODEL FOR CRITICAL CORAL REEFS ECOSYSTEMS IN MICRONESIA, INDONESIA, MALAYSIA, THE PHILIPPINES AND BEYOND.

CONSERVATION INTERNATIONAL (CI) WILL BUILD DIRECTLY ON A HIGHLY SUCCESSFUL CONSERVATION INITIATIVE IN MOROTAI (EASTERN INDONESIA'S MALUKU ISLANDS) TO STRENGTHEN EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT AND BRING ABOUT SUSTAINABLE CONSERVATION OF 10 LOCALLY MANAGED MARINE AREAS COVERING 50,000 HECTARES OF CORAL REEF HABITAT. CI WILL REINFORCE AND EXPAND CORAL REEF CONSERVATION IN THIS AREA THROUGH DEVELOPMENT OF AN OVERLAPPING BUT MUCH LARGER 100,000-HECTARE MARINE PROTECTED AREA. ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE COMMUNITY ENFORCEMENT TRAINING THAT INCLUDES USE OF VESSELS AND BIOLOGICAL AND SOCIO-ECONOMIC ASSESSMENTS THAT WILL NOT IMPACT THE ECOSYSTEMS. CI WILL USE A COMBINATION OF LINE/POINT INTERCEPT TRANSECTS AND A LESS INTENSIVE REEF CHECK METHOD. FOR SOCIOECONOMIC, THEY WILL USE A COMBINATION OF FOCUS GROUP AND KEY INFORMANT INTERVIEWS, TYPICALLY USING THE SOCMON OR SEMPAIFIKA METHODS DESCRIBED HERE: HTTPS://WWW.ICRIFORUM.ORG/SOCMON/

MPACONNECT IS A MARINE PROTECTED AREA (MPA) LEARNING NETWORK THAT HELPS BUILD MPA CAPACITY ACCORDING TO NEEDS DESCRIBED IN THE 2011 AND 2017 CARIBBEAN MPA MANAGEMENT CAPACITY ASSESSMENTS. AS MPACONNECT ENTERS A GROWTH PHASE, THIS PROPOSAL INCLUDES NETWORK COORDINATION TO COMPLEMENT OTHER CO-FUNDING OF ACTIVITIES. IT INCLUDES THE COORDINATION OF NETWORKING ACTIVITIES, THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE THIRD, FIVE-YEARLY RE-ASSESSMENT OF MPA MANAGEMENT CAPACITY AND THE UPDATING OF PRIORITY CAPACITY BUILDING NEEDS AMONG PARTICIPATING SITES, THE IMPLEMENTATION OF REGIONAL PEER-TO-PEER LEARNING EXCHANGES AND AN ANNUAL SMALL GRANTS PROGRAM TO ADDRESS CAPACITY NEEDS IN SUPPORT OF EFFECTIVE MPA IMPLEMENTATION BY CORAL REEF MANAGERS IN THE WIDER CARIBBEAN REGION. MPACONNECT WILL COLLABORATE CLOSELY WITH NOAA CRCP AND WITH MPA MANAGER MENTORS TO COORDINATE MANAGEMENT CAPACITY BUILDING INITIATIVES THAT RESPOND TO THE NEEDS OF 31 PRIORITY MPAS AND TO STONY CORAL TISSUES LOSS DISEASE WHICH A CRITICAL NEW R

THE UNIVERSITY OF HAWAII WILL ACCOMPLISH THREE TASKS: (1) STRATEGIC PLANNING: WORKING WITH INDONESIAN MANAGERS AND SCIENTISTS TO DEVELOP A PLAN TO IDENTIFY CORAL REEF FISH STOCK BOUNDARIES IN THE REGION, (2) CAPACITY BUILDING: IN-PERSON TRAINING OF INDONESIAN SCIENTISTS IN CORAL REEF FISH LIFE HISTORY STUDIES AND STOCK ASSESSMENT METHODS TO PROVIDE INFORMATION TO MANAGERS ABOUT DATA LIMITED STOCKS, AND (3) DATA SCIENCE: WORKING WITH INDONESIAN SCIENTISTS AND MANAGERS TO UTILIZES STATISTICAL METHODS TO ASSESS MARINE PROTECTED AREA (MPA) RESILIENCE AND REPRODUCTIVE CAPACITY FOR CORAL REEF FISH POPULATIONS. THERE WILL BE DATA ANALYSIS OF EXISTING DATA BUT NO FIELD WORK.

CONSERVATION INTERNATIONAL (CI) HAWAII PROPOSES TWO DISTINCT PROJECTS THAT WILL SUPPORT THE NEEDS AND AUGMENT THE TECHNICAL SUPPORT OF THE STATE OF HAWAII'S DIVISION OF AQUATIC RESOURCES (DAR) IN ITS WORK TO PROTECT HAWAII'S CORAL REEFS. THE FIRST PROJECT WILL PROVIDE ADDED CAPACITY FOR DAR TO CONDUCT AN EVALUATION OF ITS PERMITTING AND ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW PROCESSES AND DEVELOP RECOMMENDATIONS AND TRAINING TO ENABLE DAR TO IMPROVE ITS REVIEW PROCESSES IN THE FUTURE.  THE PROJECT WILL ENABLE DAR TO BETTER ALLOCATE LIMITED HUMAN AND FINANCIAL RESOURCES TO IMPROVE THE PROTECTION OF HAWAII'S CORAL REEFS. THE SECOND PROJECT WILL BUILD ON THE SUCCESSES THAT DAR SECURED IN 2021 BY HELPING DAR EXPLORE ADDITIONAL SUSTAINABLE FINANCE APPROACHES TO FUND THE NECESSARY STEWARDSHIP OF HAWAII'S MARINE RESOURCES. IN EARLY 2021, DAR CHAMPIONED STATE-LEVEL LEGISLATION THAT WOULD ULTIMATELY ESTABLISH AN OCEAN STEWARDSHIP SPECIAL FUND AND AN OCEAN STEWARDSHIP USER FEE. OCEAN TOURISM BUSINESSES, COMMUNITI

THE NATURE CONSERVANCY PROPOSES TO SUPPORT CAPACITY BUILDING NEEDS OF LOCAL CORAL REEF GOVERNOR-APPOINTED RESOURCE MANAGEMENT AGENCIES AND MANAGERS IN FLORIDA, PUERTO RICO, USVI, AMERICAN SAMOA, GUAM, AND CNMI TO EFFECTIVELY MANAGE THEIR CORAL REEFS. TNC WILL WORK CLOSELY WITH FLORIDA REEF RESILIENCE PROGRAM (FRRP) STEERING COMMITTEE MEMBERS TO IDENTIFY PROJECTS FOR THIS PROPOSAL AND SUPPORT IN WATER SURVEYS OF FLORIDAS CORAL REEFS. IN AMERICAN SAMOA TNC WILL ADDRESS THE FOLLOWING PRIORITIES: INCREASE MANAGEMENT CAPACITY OF THE CORAL REEF ADVISORY GROUP MULTIAGENCY CORAL REEF CONSERVATION COLLABORATION AND IMPROVE TERRITORIAL MANAGEMENT OF LAND-BASED SOURCES OF POLLUTION BY PROVIDING TECHNICAL SUPPORT. IN CNMI, TNC WILL ADDRESS THE FOLLOWING PRIORITIES: DEVELOPMENT OF A SAIPAN WESTERN LAGOON CORAL REEF FISHERIES ECOSYSTEM MANAGEMENT PLAN AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO SUPPORT THE DEVELOPMENT OF CNMIS CORAL RESTORATION PROGRAM INCLUDING IN WATER TRAINING. THIS PROJECT WILL EVALUATE 27 MARINE PROTECTED AREAS (MPA) LOCATED WITHIN PUERTO RICO. IN A TWO-YEAR PERIOD, PROTECTORES DE CUENCAS (PDC) PROPOSES TO COLLABORATE WITH THE PUERTO RICO DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL RESOURCES (PRDNER) TO ADDRESS PRIORITIES 1 AND 2 DEVELOPED BY THE PRDNER, WHICH ARE TO ENHANCE AND STRENGTHEN CAPACITY FOR THE DNER RANGER CORPS, AND TO WORK WITH LOCAL PARTNERS TO IMPLEMENT AND UPDATE MPA PLANS. AFTER CONSOLIDATING AVAILABLE INFORMATION ON EACH MPA, CONDUCTING SITE VISITS, AND ASSESSING ASSOCIATED SUB-WATERSHEDS, PDC WILL HOLD SIX ROUNDTABLE MEETINGS WITH STAKEHOLDERS INCLUDING THE PRDNER AND PRDNER RANGER CORPS, NATIONAL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION (NOAA), MUNICIPALITIES, MPA MANAGEMENT COMMITTEES, LOCAL NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS (NGOS), AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS. THESE MEETINGS WILL BE USED TO SHARE RESULTS OF THE LITERATURE REVIEW, IDENTIFY THE MAIN THREATS, DETERMINE NEEDS, AND RECOMMEND ACTIONS TO IMPROVE MANAGEMENT IN EACH MPA. IN

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE EDUCATION AND TRAINING TO THE HAWAII DIVISION OF AQUATIC RESOURCES (DAR) SO THE AGENCY CAN INTEGRATE AN UNDERWATER 3DIMENSIONA MAPPING ANALYTICAL PIPELINE INTO THEIR MONITORING PROGRAM TO ACCURATELY MEASURE HOW CHANGING CORAL HABITATS INFLUENCE BIODIVERSITY, ECOSYSTEM FUNCTION, AND AVAILABILITY OF ECOSYSTEM SERVICES. 3D RECONSTRUCTION TECHNIQUES PRODUCE CO-LOCATED PHOTOMOSAICS AND DIGITAL ELEVATION MODEL (DEM). PHOTOMOSAIC AND DEM PROCESSING IS AN ADVANCED ANALYTICAL APPROACH THAT CAN GREATLY INCREASE DAR'S ABILITY TO TRACK CHANGES IN BENTHIC CONDITIONS AND EXAMINE HOW CHANGES IN CORAL HEALTH AND MORTALITY ALTER HABITAT COMPLEXITY AND ECOLOGICAL PROCESSES. PHOTOMOSAICS HAVE BEEN USED FOR A RANGE OF TASKS WITHIN REEF SYSTEMS INCLUDING BENTHIC HABITAT MAPPING, ANALYSIS OF SEAFLOOR TOPOGRAPHY, AND ASSESSMENT OF FINE SCALE CHANGES IN REEF ENVIRONMENTS. THIS PROJECT CAN HELP DAR CONNECT 3D HABITAT DATA DERIVED FROM PHOTOMOSAICS AND DEMS WITH CO-LOCATED

THIS PROJECT AIMS TO DETERMINE THE OPTIMAL LIGHT TO REAR SENSITIVE CORAL RECRUITS IN ORDER TO RAPIDLY AND EFFECTIVELY UPSCALE PRODUCTION OF GENETICALLY-DIVERSE CORALS FOR RESTORATION. NOVA SOUTHEASTERN UNIVERSITY WORKING WITH MOTE MARINE LABORATORY, THE FLORIDA AQUARIUM, AND THE UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA, WILMINGTON WILL CONDUCT A SET OF COORDINATED AND PARALLEL STUDIES ACROSS THE FOUR LAND-BASED CORAL NURSERY FACILITIES TO TEST AND COMPARE THE IMPACT OF DIFFERENT LIGHT TREATMENTS ON EARLY GROWTH FOR LEAST TWO REEF-BUILDING CORAL SPECIES ENDEMIC TO FLORIDA. THESE INSTITUTIONS WILL TEST THE EFFECT OF ARTIFICIAL LIGHT THAT MIMICS THE LIGHT SPECTRUM AT THE REEF DEPTH AND USE A PRESET LIGHT SPECTRUM AND COMPARE THESE WITH NATURAL LIGHT  IN ORDER TO DETERMINE THE OPTIMAL SETTINGS TO ENHANCE GROWTH REDUCE LAND-BASED REARING TIME OF YOUNG CORALS FOR CORAL REEF RESTORATION. THEY WILL ALSO CHARACTERIZE THE MICROBIOME AND SYMBIONT COMPOSITION IN THE YOUNG RECRUITS IN EACH FACILITY.

THIS PROJECT WILL STRENGTHEN AND EXPAND A PEER LEARNING NETWORK OF CARIBBEAN MARINE PROTECTED AREAS (MPAS) KNOWN AS MPACONNECT. IT RESPONDS DIRECTLY TO AN INTERAGENCY AGREEMENT (IAA) BETWEEN NOAA AND THE US AGENCY FOR INTERNATIONAL ASSISTANCE (USAID) THAT CALLS FOR NOAA AND USAID TO WORK WITH THE GULF AND CARIBBEAN FISHERIES INSTITUTE (GCFI) TO PROMOTE REGIONAL STABILITY OF MPAS IN THE CARIBBEAN REGION. GCFI WILL INVITE NEW MPA SITES TO THE MPACONNECT NETWORK AND ASSESS THEIR MANAGEMENT CAPACITY TO HELP GUIDE CAPACITY BUILDING AND NETWORKING ACTIVITIES. IN COLLABORATION WITH THE NOAA CORAL REEF CONSERVATION PROGRAM (CRCP), GCFI WILL COORDINATE MANAGEMENT CAPACITY BUILDING ACTIVITIES THAT RESPOND TO THE SPECIFIC NEEDS OF NEW AND EXISTING MPACONNECT MEMBERS THROUGH PEER EXCHANGES, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, AND SMALL GRANTS.  IT WILL ALSO ADDRESS REGIONAL MPA MANAGEMENT PRIORITIES AND EMERGING ISSUES WITH AN EMPHASIS ON PROMOTING SUSTAINABLE FINANCING AND RESPONDING TO STONY CORAL TISSUE LOSS
FLORIDA'S FY21-22 CORAL REEF CONSERVATION COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT
AS FY21-22 CRCP STATE AND TERRITORY CORAL REEF CONSERVATION AGREEMENT

THE TERRITORY OF GUAM'S CORAL REEF CONSERVATION PROGRAM FUNDS WILL SUPPORT FIVE PROGRAM TASKS: 1) CORAL REEF MANAGEMENT STAFF POSITIONS (WATERSHED COORDINATOR AND CORAL REEF INITIATIVE MANAGER), 2) TRAVEL TO ALL ISLANDS COMMITTEE AND US CORAL REEF TASK FORCE MEETINGS, 3) ALL ISLANDS COMMITTEE DUES, 4) CORAL REEF MANAGEMENT FELLOWSHIP PROGRAM; AND 5) COMPREHENSIVE LONG-TERM CORAL REEF MONITORING. GUAM WILL ALSO IMPLEMENT: 1) PUBLIC EDUCATION AND OUTREACH ABOUT THE ENVIRONMENT; 2) MICRONESIA CHALLENGE DUES; 3) REPLACE AND INSTALL MARINE PRESERVE RANGE MARKERS; AND 4) INSTALL GREEN INFRASTRUCTURE TO DECREASE FLOODING AND RUN-OFF.

TO ADDRESS RECENT THREATS, THIS AWARD WILL HELP BUILD HAWAII'S DIVISION OF AQUATIC RESOURCES ITS CAPACITY TO MONITOR AND PROTECT THE STATE'S THREATENED REEFS. PROJECTS INCLUDE DETAILED MONITORING OF CORAL REEF CONDITIONS IN THE ISLAND OF HAWAII AND SURVEYS STATEWIDE, COORDINATION OF WATERSHED-LEVEL ACTIVITIES (TO REDUCE SEDIMENTS GOING INTO THE REEFS), FIRE PREVENTION PROJECTS (TO AVOID EXCESSIVE SEDIMENTATION FROM REACHING THE REEFS), BETTER ENFORCEMENT (VIA ENFORCEMENT ANALYSIS, AND LEGAL FELLOWS), SUPPORT DRAFTING OF TARGETED RULES AND REGULATIONS THAT BETTER PROTECT REEFS, IMPLEMENTATION OF SITE-BASED CONSERVATION PLANS ACROSS THE STATE (UNDER THE GOAL TO CONSERVE 30% OF HAWAII'S MARINE AREAS) AS WELL AS ACTIVE RESTORATION PROJECTS.  THESE PROJECTS ARE PART OF A LARGER PLAN, BOTH AT THE STATE LEVEL AND WITH NOAA'S CORAL REEF CONSERVATION PROGRAM, TO HELP ARREST THE DECLINE OF CORAL REEFS IN THE STATE, AND TO ENABLE THE CONDITIONS NECESSARY FOR THEIR CONTINUED GROWTH.

THIS AWARD TO THE UNITED STATES VIRGIN ISLANDS (USVI) DEPARTMENT OF PLANNING AND NATURAL RESOURCES (DPNR) WILL PROVIDE FUNDS TO SUPPORT IMPLEMENTATION OF THE USVI TERRITORIAL CORAL REEF INITIATIVE, WHICH INCLUDES SEVERAL ONGOING ELEMENTS AS WELL AS A FEW NEW PROJECTS.  IN FY21 THIS AWARD WILL PROVIDE FUNDING TO CONTINUE THE TERRITORIAL CORAL REEF MONITORING PROGRAM (TCRMP) AND SUPPORT A FEW ADDITIONAL SMALLER TCRMP PROJECTS INCLUDING CORAL RECRUITMENT MONITORING, CORAL INTERACTIONS DATA ANALYSES, AND A REVAMP OF THE TCRMP WEBSITE. THIS AWARD WILL ALSO CONTINUE TO PROVIDE STAFF SUPPORT FOR THE USVI CORAL REEF INITIATIVE THROUGH THE CORAL REEF INITIATIVE COORDINATOR, THE EAST END MARINE PARK EDUCATION AND OUTREACH COORDINATOR, AND THE EAST END MARINE PARK RANGER.   ADDITIONALLY, FUNDS FROM THIS AWARD WILL SUPPORT PROJECTS INCLUDING: (1) THE CREATION OF AN INTERPRETIVE RANGER APPRENTICE IN THE EAST END MARINE PARK, (2) CONTINUED MAINTENANCE OF AN EXISTING CORAL NURSERY DEMONSTRATION S
CNMIS FY21-22 CRCP STATE AND TERRITORY CORAL REEF CONSERVATION COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT

THE PUERTO RICO DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL RESOURCES (DNER) IS RESPONSIBLE FOR CORAL REEF CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT WITHIN THE COMMONWEALTH'S JURISDICTIONAL WATERS. SINCE 1998, DNER AND THE NATIONAL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION HAVE PARTNERED TO MONITOR AND IMPLEMENT CONSERVATION PROJECTS THROUGH COOPERATIVE AGREEMENTS. DURING THE NEXT TWO YEARS, THE FOLLOWING TASKS AND PROJECTS WILL BE IMPLEMENTED THROUGH THIS AGREEMENT: (1) PROGRAM COORDINATION, ADMINISTRATION AND PRIORITY AREAS MANAGEMENT SUPPORT; (2) CORAL REEF MONITORING PROGRAM, WHICH INCLUDES LONG-TERM CORAL MONITORING AND A CORAL REEF SPECIALIST POSITION; (3) CORAL REEF EDUCATION AND OUTREACH; (4) NORTHEAST MANAGEMENT AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT; (5) CORAL REEF EMERGENCIES PREPAREDNESS AND RESPONSE; (6) STONY CORAL TISSUE LOSS DISEASE INTERVENTION; (7) GROUNDING RESPONSE AND NAUTICAL COMMUNITY KNOWLEDGE ASSESSMENT; (8) RE-STOCKING OF THE KEYSTONE HERBIVORE SPECIES DIADEMA ANTILLARUM TO REDUCE ALGAE OVERGRO
NOVEL DEVICES FOR THE OUTPLANTING OF SEXUAL AND ASEXUAL CORAL PROPAGULES

FLORIDA INTERNATIONAL UNIVERSITY (FIU) WILL INVESTIGATE THE FEASIBILITY TO IMPROVE RESTORATION AND ENHANCE CORAL RESILIENCE VIA CORAL STRESS HARDENING. FIU WILL CONDUCT LABORATORY AND FIELD EXPERIMENTS TO FILL CRITICAL KNOWLEDGE GAPS (E.G., TREATMENT DOSE, STRESSOR SPECIFICITY, POTENTIAL BENEFITS AND TRADE-OFFS, AND THE MOLECULAR MECHANISMS OF HARDENING. THIS WORK WILL (1) OPTIMIZE STRESS HARDENING DOSES; (2) ASSESS THE PHYSIOLOGICAL COSTS AND BENEFITS OF STRESS HARDENING; (3) IDENTIFY THE MOLECULAR MECHANISMS RESPONSIBLE FOR HARDENED PHENOTYPES AND POTENTIAL BIOMARKERS FOR ENHANCED STRESS TOLERANCE IN CORALS; AND (4) TRACK THE HEALTH AND THERMAL PERFORMANCE OF OUTPLANTED CORALS FOR MORE THAN A YEAR AFTER HARDENING IN AN EXISTING RESTORATION PROGRAM. CORAL HEALTH/STRESS METRICS WILL BE MEASURED TO DETERMINE THE COSTS AND BENEFITS OF ACUTE AND EXTENDED THERMAL STRESS HARDENING, EXTENDED NUTRIENT STRESS HARDENING, AND THE COMBINATION OF BOTH.
